title: Vanderbilt Biostatistics Summer Internship: Regression
text: This is a series of five 90 minute lectures taught by Simon as part of the Department of Biostatistics Summer Internship at Vanderbilt University. The course is part two of a 10 day series to introduce undergraduate students interested in medical science, biology, and mathematics to Biostatistical methods.

title: Class 1

We will use linear regression to analyze the FEV dataset.

title: Class 1
text:
Introductions

What is your name, year, major, goal for post graduation (ok if you don’t know yet)?
What is your experience with math/R? How about Rstudio?
Discuss internship projects, so far.

title: Class 1
text:
Simple linear regression

Definition:

Simple linear regression is a statistical method used to model the relationship between two variables by fitting a linear equation to observed data.

Equation:

The equation for a simple linear regression is:
\[
Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X + \epsilon
\]
\(Y\): Dependent variable (outcome)
\(X\): Independent variable (predictor)
\(\beta_0\): Intercept (value of \(Y\) when \(X = 0\))
\(\beta_1\): Slope (change in \(Y\) for a one-unit change in \(X\))
\(\epsilon\): Error term (captures variability not explained by the model)

Goal:

To estimate the coefficients (\(\beta_0\) and \(\beta_1\)) that quantify the association of \(Y\) and \(X\).

Interpretation:

Intercept (\(\beta_0\)): The expected value (mean) of \(Y\) when \(X\) is zero.
Slope (\(\beta_1\)): Represents the average change in \(Y\) for each one-unit increase in \(X\).



Example: FEV and Smoking
The code below loads in the data. Forced Expiratory Volume (FEV), is a lung function test that measures how much air a person can exhale during a forced breath.


Code
fev = read.csv('Datasets/FEV.csv')
fev$smoke = relevel(as.factor(fev$smoke), ref='non-current smoker')


Exercise: Create a plot showing a histogram of the FEV variable.


Code
hist(fev$fev)






Boxplot visualization
This is a visualization of the association between FEV and smoking status before fitting a linear regression.


Code
library(ggplot2)
ggplot(fev, aes(x = smoke, y = fev)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(title = "FEV by smoking status", x = "Smoking status", y = "FEV")






How can we test whether FEV is different between “non-current smoker” and “current smoker”?
The variable smoking status is our \(X\) variable and FEV is our \(Y\) variable. \(X\) is a categorical variable, how can we code \(X\) for this model?

Exercise: Perform a t-test of smoking status. Set the option var.equal = TRUE. Interpret the results of all the output.


Code
t.test(fev ~ smoke, data = fev, var.equal = TRUE)



    Two Sample t-test

data:  fev by smoke
t = -6.4645, df = 652, p-value = 1.993e-10
alternative hypothesis: true difference in means between group non-current smoker and group current smoker is not equal to 0
95 percent confidence interval:
 -0.9266033 -0.4948346
sample estimates:
mean in group non-current smoker     mean in group current smoker 
                        2.566143                         3.276862 




Fitting the linear regression model

The code below fits two models in R. What are they doing?
What output below looks familiar to you? Interpret the results.



Code
# Fit linear regression with factor variable
model_factor <- lm(fev ~ smoke, data = fev)
summary(model_factor)



Call:
lm(formula = fev ~ smoke, data = fev)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-1.7751 -0.6339 -0.1021  0.4804  3.2269 

Coefficients:
                    Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)          2.56614    0.03466  74.037  < 2e-16 ***
smokecurrent smoker  0.71072    0.10994   6.464 1.99e-10 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 0.8412 on 652 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.06023,   Adjusted R-squared:  0.05879 
F-statistic: 41.79 on 1 and 652 DF,  p-value: 1.993e-10


Code
# Fit linear regression with binary variable
fev$smoke_binary <- ifelse(fev$smoke == "current smoker", 1, 0)
model_binary <- lm(fev ~ smoke_binary, data = fev)
summary(model_binary)



Call:
lm(formula = fev ~ smoke_binary, data = fev)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-1.7751 -0.6339 -0.1021  0.4804  3.2269 

Coefficients:
             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)   2.56614    0.03466  74.037  < 2e-16 ***
smoke_binary  0.71072    0.10994   6.464 1.99e-10 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 0.8412 on 652 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.06023,   Adjusted R-squared:  0.05879 
F-statistic: 41.79 on 1 and 652 DF,  p-value: 1.993e-10




Creating visualizations
The following code creates a nice table output that you would want to put in a report for your projects.


Code
library(sjPlot)

# Create a results table 
tab_model(model_factor)





 
fev


Predictors
Estimates
CI

(Intercept)
2.57
2.50 – 2.63
<0.001


smoke [current smoker]
0.71
0.49 – 0.93
<0.001


Observations
654


R2 / R2 adjusted
0.060 / 0.059







Next, we plot the results from the model to see what the fitted model looks like.


Code
library(emmeans)

# Estimated means
means <- emmeans(model_factor, ~ smoke)

# Scatter plot of estimated means
library(ggplot2)

plot_data <- as.data.frame(means)
ggplot(plot_data, aes(x = smoke, y = emmean)) +
  geom_point(size = 4) +
  geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = lower.CL, ymax = upper.CL), width = 0.2) +
  #geom_point(data = fev, aes(x = smoke, y = fev), alpha = 0.5, position = position_dodge(width = 0.4)) +
  # example with jitter, comment out the other line
  geom_jitter(data = fev, aes(x = smoke, y = fev), alpha = 0.5) +
  labs(title = "Estimated Means with FEV", x = "Smoking status", y = "Estimated Mean FEV")





To analyze the effect of a continuous variable “age” using simple linear regression, here’s a similar structure as you provided for the categorical variable “smoke” while focusing on “age”:



Example: FEV and Age
Performs data analysis of (FEV) with respect to age:

Scatter Plot Visualization
This is a visualization of the association between FEV and age before fitting a linear regression.


Code
# Scatter plot of FEV by age
ggplot(fev, aes(x = age, y = fev)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  labs(title = "FEV by Age", x = "Age", y = "FEV")






How can we test the relationship between FEV and age?
The variable age is our \(X\) variable and FEV is our \(Y\) variable. \(X\) is a continuous variable. How can it be incorporated into the model?



Fitting the Linear Regression Model

The code below fits the model in R. How does it show the relationship between FEV and age?
What output below looks familiar to you? Interpret the results.



Code
# Fit linear regression with age as the predictor
model_age <- lm(fev ~ age, data = fev)




Creating Visualizations
The following code creates a nice table output that you would want for your report:


Code
# Create a results table 
tab_model(model_age)





 
fev


Predictors
Estimates
CI
p


(Intercept)
0.43
0.28 – 0.58
<0.001


age
0.22
0.21 – 0.24
<0.001


Observations
654


R2 / R2 adjusted
0.572 / 0.572







Next, we plot the results from the model to see what the relationship looks like:


Code
# Estimated regression line
ageGrid = ref_grid(model_age, at=list(age=seq(min(fev$age), max(fev$age), length.out=100)) )
predictions <- emmeans(ageGrid, ~age)

# Prepare data for plotting
pred_plot_data <- as.data.frame(predictions)

# Scatter plot with regression line
ggplot() +
  geom_point(data = fev, aes(x = age, y = fev), alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_ribbon(data = pred_plot_data, aes(x = age, ymin = lower.CL, ymax = upper.CL), alpha = 0.7, fill = "grey") +
  geom_line(data = pred_plot_data, aes(x = age, y = emmean), color = "red", linewidth = 1) +
  labs(title = "FEV vs. Age with Regression Line", x = "Age", y = "FEV")





This setup analyzes the effect of the continuous variable “age” on FEV using simple linear regression, from fitting the model to visualizing the results. Adjust the dataset path and specifics according to your actual data and requirements.



Assumptions

What are some assumptions we’ve made here?


Linearity
Homoskedasticity
Normality (sort of)

title: Class 1
text: Multiple regression

title: Class 2
text:
Know how to interpret regression coefficients in multiple regression
Understand output from multiple regression

Tests

T-tests
F-tests

R-square

Understand assumptions of regression

title: Class 2
text:
Multiple covariates
In multiple regression, the model includes multiple predictors. For example, with age and smoking status as covariates:
\[
\text{FEV} = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \times \text{age} + \beta_2 \times \text{smoke} + \epsilon
\]
Where:

\(\beta_0\) is the intercept.
\(\beta_1\) is the change in FEV for a one-unit change in age, holding smoke constant.
\(\beta_2\) is the difference in FEV between smokers and non-smokers, holding age constant.

title: Class 2
text:
Example: Age and smoking

Specifying the model



Code
# Load the necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(emmeans)
library(sjPlot)

# Load the dataset
fev <- read.csv('Datasets/FEV.csv')

# Convert smoking status to a factor
fev$smoke <- factor(fev$smoke, levels = c('non-current smoker', 'current smoker'))

# Specify and fit the model
model <- lm(fev ~ age + smoke, data = fev)
summary(model)



Call:
lm(formula = fev ~ age + smoke, data = fev)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-1.6653 -0.3564 -0.0508  0.3494  2.0894 

Coefficients:
                     Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)          0.367373   0.081436   4.511 7.65e-06 ***
age                  0.230605   0.008184  28.176  < 2e-16 ***
smokecurrent smoker -0.208995   0.080745  -2.588  0.00986 ** 
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 0.5651 on 651 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.5766,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.5753 
F-statistic: 443.3 on 2 and 651 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


Code
tab_model(model)





 
fev

Exercise: Interpret the coefficients as described above. Use the coefficients table output to discuss individual predictors.

Interpretation of tests



Code
library(kableExtra)
# t-tests are part of the summary output, indicating significance of individual coefficients
# F-tests assess the overall significance, frequently output in the summary table
kable(anova(model), format='html', caption='ANOVA table', digits=2)

Using emmeans or effects to plot age effects



Code
# Estimated regression line
ageGrid = ref_grid(model, at=list(age=seq(min(fev$age), max(fev$age), length.out=100)) )
predictions <- emmeans(ageGrid, ~age)

# Prepare data for plotting
pred_plot_data <- as.data.frame(predictions)

# Scatter plot with regression line
ggplot() +
  geom_point(data = fev, aes(x = age, y = fev, color = smoke), alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_ribbon(data = pred_plot_data, aes(x = age, ymin = lower.CL, ymax = upper.CL), alpha = 0.7, fill = "grey") +
  geom_line(data = pred_plot_data, aes(x = age, y = emmean), color = "red", linewidth = 1) +
  labs(title = "FEV vs. Age with Regression Line", x = "Age", y = "FEV")






Using emmeans or effects to plot smoking effects



Code
library(emmeans)

# Estimated means
means <- emmeans(model, ~ smoke)

# Scatter plot of estimated means
library(ggplot2)

plot_data <- as.data.frame(means)
ggplot(plot_data, aes(x = smoke, y = emmean)) +
  geom_point(size = 4) +
  geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = lower.CL, ymax = upper.CL), width = 0.2) +
  #geom_point(data = fev, aes(x = smoke, y = fev), alpha = 0.5, position = position_dodge(width = 0.4)) +
  # example with jitter, comment out the other line
  #geom_jitter(data = fev, aes(x = smoke, y = fev), alpha = 0.5) +
  labs(title = "Estimated Means with FEV", x = "Smoking status", y = "Estimated Mean FEV")






Added variable plots are useful for visualizing the effect of one variable removing the effect of all the other variables
Here, it is interesting for visualizing the smoking effect

title: Class 2
text:
Example: Age, smoking, sex

Interpretation of parameter estimates

Exercise: Add sex to the model, create the output using summary and tab_model, and interpret the coefficients for all variables.


Code
model1<-lm(fev~age+smoke+sex,data=fev)
summary(model1)



Call:
lm(formula = fev ~ age + smoke + sex, data = fev)

Residuals:

-1.46707 -0.35426 -0.03811  0.32199  1.94943

(Intercept)          0.237771   0.080228   2.964  0.00315 ** 
age                  0.226794   0.007884  28.765  < 2e-16 ***
smokecurrent smoker -0.153974   0.077977  -1.975  0.04873 *  
sexmale              0.315273   0.042710   7.382  4.8e-13 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 0.5432 on 650 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.6093,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.6075 
F-statistic: 337.9 on 3 and 650 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


Code
tab_model(model1)

Interpretation of tests

Exercise: Create the anova table and discuss the results.

title: Class 2
text:
Regression Model with Interaction
Consider a regression model:
\[
\text{FEV} = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \times \text{age} + \beta_2 \times \text{sex} + \beta_3 \times (\text{age} \times \text{sex}) + \epsilon
\]
Where: - \(\text{sex}\) is a binary variable (0 for females, 1 for males).

title: Class 2
text:
Interpretation of Coefficients

\(\beta_0\): Intercept

The expected FEV for females (\(\text{sex} = 0\)) when age is zero.

\(\beta_1\): Main effect of age

The change in FEV associated with a one-unit increase in age for females (\(\text{sex} = 0\)).

\(\beta_2\): Main effect of sex

The difference in expected FEV between males and females at age zero.

\(\beta_3\): Interaction term (age by sex)

The additional change in the effect of age on FEV for males compared to females. This coefficient reflects how the effect of age on FEV differs between sexes.



For Females (\(\text{sex} = 0\)):
[ = _0 + _1 ] The slope with respect to age is \(\beta_1\).
For Males (\(\text{sex} = 1\)):
[ = (_0 + _2) + (_1 + _3) ] The slope with respect to age is \(\beta_1 + \beta_3\), indicating the modified effect of age for males.
The interaction term (\(\beta_3\)) alters the model by adding separate age effects for males and females. A significant \(\beta_3\) suggests that the relationship between age and FEV differs between males and females.

title: Class 2
text:
Example: Age by sex interaction
Now we investigate the interaction between age and smoking.


Code
# Model with interaction
model_interaction <- lm(fev ~ age * sex, data = fev)
summary(model_interaction)



Call:
lm(formula = fev ~ age * sex, data = fev)

Residuals:
     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
-1.64072 -0.34337 -0.04934  0.33206  1.86867 

Coefficients:
             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)  0.849467   0.102199   8.312 5.51e-16 ***
age          0.162729   0.009952  16.351  < 2e-16 ***
sexmale     -0.775867   0.142745  -5.435 7.74e-08 ***
age:sexmale  0.110749   0.013786   8.033 4.47e-15 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 0.5196 on 650 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.6425,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.6408 
F-statistic: 389.4 on 3 and 650 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16



Interpretation of tests and type 2 sum of squares using car::Anova



Code
library(car)
Anova(model_interaction, type = 2)


Anova Table (Type II tests)

Response: fev
           Sum Sq  Df  F value    Pr(>F)    
age       276.661   1 1024.615 < 2.2e-16 ***
sex        17.066   1   63.203 8.270e-15 ***
age:sex    17.426   1   64.535 4.467e-15 ***
Residuals 175.509 650                       
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

title: Class 2
text:
R-square
The R-square value in the model output helps us gauge how well our model explains the variability in the data.

title: Class 2
text:
Diagnostic plots for lm


Code
# makes the plots look nice
par(mfrow=c(2,2), mgp=c(1.7,.7,0), lwd=1.5, lend=2,
    cex.lab=1, cex.axis=1, cex.main=1,
    mar=c(2.8,2.8,1.8,.2), bty='l', oma=c(0,0,2,0))
# Plot diagnostics
plot(model_interaction)

title: Class 2
text:
Normality

For t-tests and F-tests, we assume the errors are normally distributed
If they are not, you learned about a theorem that makes them valid (from Gustavo). What was the theorem?
The residuals are the data version of the error and you can visualize them to see if they are normally distributed, especially important for hypothesis testing.


Visualization

Histogram of residuals



Code
hist(residuals(model_interaction), breaks = 20, main = "Histogram of Residuals", xlab = "Residuals")






Normal QQ plot of the residuals



Code
qqnorm(scale(residuals(model_interaction)))
qqline(scale(residuals(model_interaction)), col = "red")

title: Class 2
text:
Homoskedasticity
Assess constant variance of residuals using a plot.


Code
plot(model_interaction$fitted.values, residuals(model_interaction), main = "Residuals vs Fitted", xlab = "Fitted values", ylab = "Residuals")






Transformations

Log transformation



Code
# Log-transform the response and re-fit the model
model_log <- lm(log(fev) ~ age + smoke + sex, data = fev)
summary(model_log)



Call:
lm(formula = log(fev) ~ age + smoke + sex, data = fev)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-0.6668 -0.1287  0.0003  0.1464  0.5494 

Coefficients:
                     Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)         -0.015818   0.030370  -0.521   0.6027    
age                  0.089629   0.002985  30.030  < 2e-16 ***
smokecurrent smoker -0.073473   0.029518  -2.489   0.0131 *  
sexmale              0.094282   0.016168   5.831 8.66e-09 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 0.2056 on 650 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.6211,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.6193 
F-statistic: 355.1 on 3 and 650 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


New interpretation of parameters: Log-transforming the response variable changes the interpretation of the parameters.
When you fit a regression model with a log-transformed dependent variable, such as \(\log(\text{FEV})\), but you want to interpret the effects on the untransformed scale, you need to understand the multiplicative nature of the changes.

Regression Model
Consider a model: \[
\log(\text{FEV}) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \cdot \text{age} + \beta_2 \cdot \text{smoke} + \beta_3 \cdot \text{sex} + \epsilon
\]
Where: - \(\text{smoke}\): Binary variable (e.g., 0 for non-current smokers, 1 for current smokers). - \(\text{sex}\): Binary variable (e.g., 0 for females, 1 for males).


Interpreting Coefficients on the Untransformed Scale

Intercept (\(\beta_0\)):

The exponentiated intercept, \(e^{\beta_0}\), represents the expected FEV for the reference group (e.g., non-current smokers and females) when age is zero. However, an age of zero may not be meaningful, so the intercept alone is less interpretable.

Age Coefficient (\(\beta_1\)):

\(e^{\beta_1}\) represents the multiplicative change in the expected FEV for each additional year of age, holding other factors constant. Specifically, it means a \(100 \times (e^{\beta_1} - 1)\%\) change in FEV per unit increase in age.

Smoking Status Coefficient (\(\beta_2\)):

\(e^{\beta_2}\) represents the expected multiplicative change in FEV when comparing current smokers to non-current smokers, holding other factors constant. It translates to a \(100 \times (e^{\beta_2} - 1)\%\) difference in expected FEV between these groups.

Sex Coefficient (\(\beta_3\)):

\(e^{\beta_3}\) represents the expected multiplicative change in FEV when comparing males to females, holding age and smoking status constant. This is interpreted as a \(100 \times (e^{\beta_3} - 1)\%\) change in expected FEV.





Robust (sandwich) standard errors
We don’t have to apply a transformation to get valid results when there is heteroskedasticity.


Code
library(sandwich)

# Compute robust standard errors
tab_model(model_interaction, vcov.fun = vcovHC(model_interaction))





 
fev


Predictors
Estimates
CI
p


(Intercept)
0.85
0.68 – 1.02
<0.001


age
0.16
0.14 – 0.18
<0.001


sex [male]
-0.78
-1.04 – -0.51
<0.001


age × sex [male]
0.11
0.08 – 0.14
<0.001


Observations
654


R2 / R2 adjusted
0.642 / 0.641

title: Class 2
text: Linearity

title: Class 2
text:
Polynomials


Code
# Polynomial term for age
model_poly <- lm(fev ~ poly(age, 2) + smoke + sex, data = fev)
summary(model_poly)



Call:
lm(formula = fev ~ poly(age, 2) + smoke + sex, data = fev)

Residuals:
     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
-1.40214 -0.35307 -0.03349  0.32630  1.93284 

Coefficients:
                    Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)          2.48338    0.03165  78.467  < 2e-16 ***
poly(age, 2)1       16.95796    0.58876  28.803  < 2e-16 ***
poly(age, 2)2       -2.30190    0.54295  -4.240 2.56e-05 ***
smokecurrent smoker -0.10214    0.07794  -1.310    0.191    
sexmale              0.31834    0.04217   7.549 1.49e-13 ***
---

title: Class 3
text:
Age Influence on Health Charges:
To evaluate the effect of age on medical charges, we performed a test of the linear age effect using a T-test and report the effect with the estimate, confidence interval, T-statistic, degrees of freedom, and \(p\)-value.
There was evidence that age was positive associated with medical charges (b=258.54, StdEr=11.94, \(T=21.66\), \(df=1300\), \(p <0.001\)).

title: Class 3
text:
Equal variance assumption

Use Robust standard errors. Also called Heteroskedasticity consistent standard errors or sandwich standard errors.



Code
library(sandwich)
library(car)

car::Anova(modelNonlinear)

title: Class 4: Logistic regression
text:
Interpret logistic regression coefficients.
Evaluate

title: Class 4: Logistic regression
text:
Model
Logistic regression model predicts the log odds of the binary outcome (e.g., whether an individual is a smoker or not) as a linear combination of the predictor variables.
The model can be formulated as: \[
   \text{logit}(p) = \log\left(\frac{p}{1 - p}\right) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_1 + \beta_2 X_2 + \ldots + \beta_k X_k
   \] where: - $ p $ is the probability of the outcome (smoking = 1). - $ X_1, X_2, , X_k $ are the predictor variables (age, sex, region). - $ _0 $ is the intercept. - $ _1, _2, , _k $ are the coefficients for the predictors.

title: Class 4: Logistic regression
section: Intepreting coefficients on the log-odds scale
text:
Intepreting coefficients on the log-odds scale
Each coefficient $ _i $ represents the change in the log odds of the outcome for a one-unit increase in the corresponding predictor variable $ X_i $, holding all other predictors constant.

For continuous predictors (e.g., Age):

If $ _1 =-0.004$ (age): for every 1-year increase in age, the log odds of being a smoker increase by 0.05.

For categorical predictors (e.g., Sex and Region):

If $ _2 = 0.37$, then being male decreases the log odds of being a smoker by 1.5.

title: Class 4: Logistic regression
section: Interpreting coefficients on the odds scale
text:
Interpreting coefficients on the odds scale

To convert the log odds to odds, we exponentiate: [ = e^{(p)} = e^{_0 + _1 X_1 + _2 X_2 + + _k X_k} ]
Odds Ratio (OR):

The odds ratio for a one-unit increase in $ X_i $ is given by: [ = e^{_i} ]
This tells us how the odds of the outcome change with a one-unit increase in $ X_i $:

If $ > 1 $, the odds of being a smoker increase (more likely).
If $ < 1 $, the odds of being a smoker decrease (less likely).
If $ = 1 $, there is no change in the odds.

title: Class 4: Logistic regression
text: Example Interpretation

title: Class 4: Logistic regression
text:
Example visualization


Code
# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)



Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union


Code
# Create a new dataframe for predictions
ins$predicted_prob = predict(glmModel, type = "link")

# Create a visualization of predicted probabilities against age
ggplot(ins, aes(x = age, y = predicted_prob, color = sex)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6) +
  geom_smooth(method = "loess", se = FALSE, color = "black") +
  labs(title = "Predicted Probability of Smoking by Age",
       x = "Age",
       y = "Predicted Probability of Smoking") +
  theme_minimal()


`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Class 4: Logistic regression
text:
Robust standard errors
I like to use robust standard errors for testing whenever I can. They are also possible for the glm function.


Code
library(sandwich) 
library(lmtest)


Loading required package: zoo



Attaching package: 'zoo'


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    as.Date, as.Date.numeric


Code
coeftest(glmModel, vcov = vcovHC(glmModel))
